biases.name: Chronological Snobbery Fallacy
biases.description: The Chronological Snobbery Fallacy is a bias against arguments, thought, or work from historically earlier time periods because they are perceived as having arisen at a “less advanced” time period than the present.
biases.examples: For example, it has been believed that getting enough sleep is beneficial for health for many years; for example, Aristotle reportedly believed that sleep [was important](https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2014/11/a-brief-history-of-sleep/) at a time when lots of inaccurate things were also believed. But this does not make the belief that sleep is important for health an invalid one (indeed, there are many longitudinal studies demonstrating measurable health benefits associated with adequate [but not excessive] levels of sleep).

biases.name: Conjunction Fallacy
biases.description: The Conjunction Fallacy is a logical reasoning fallacy wherein someone assigns a lower probability to an event occurring in general than to the event occurring in combination with another event (in “conjunction” with another event).
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In one experiment, subjects were presented with the following scenario: Linda is 31 years old, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy. As a student, she was deeply concerned with issues of discrimination and social justice, and also participated in anti-nuclear demonstrations.

Which is more probable?

1. Linda is a bank teller.
2. Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement.

85% of those asked chose option 2. However, the probability of two events occurring together (in "conjunction") is always less than or equal to the probability of either one occurring alone. But in another study, the question was rephrased in a more concrete format, and participants were likely to get the answer right. This demonstrates that it may be a result of poor word choice, rather than bias, that causes subjects to create unrealistic associations.
biases.wasEvidenceCopypastedFromSomewhereIfSoHa: If we just wanted to give an overview of the historical origins of experiment demonstrations of this error, then it seems fine to just reword this. But if we wanted to give more recent evidence, we'd need to look for further info elsewhere. Currently, the cell's content is taken from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunction_fallacy
biases.examples:
For example, someone might believe that it's more likely that they'll draw *two* aces from a deck of cards than that they'll draw just a *single* ace.

One can also see this fallacy present in conspiracism (in addition to other fallacies), where proponents of a particular conspiracy believe that it's more likely that many outlandish events occurred than that a few mundane events occurred. biases.name: Disjunction Fallacy
biases.description: The Disjunction Fallacy refers to an error in probabilistic reasoning whereby people estimate that the probability of an event happening exceeds the probability of either that event or another event happening. The probability that either event (A or B) occurs will always be larger than the individual probabilities of A occurring or of B occurring.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Further evidence that the Representativeness Heuristic may be causal to the Disjunction Fallacy comes from Bar-Hillel and Neter (1986). They found that people judge a person who is highly representative of being a statistics major (e.g., highly intelligent, does math competitions) as being more likely to be a statistics major than a social sciences major (superset of statistics), but they do not think that he is more likely to be a Hebrew language major than a humanities major (superset of Hebrew language). Thus, only when the person seems highly representative of a category is that category judged as more probable than its superordinate category. For example, the probability of being either a physics or a biology major is at least as likely as being a physics major, if not more likely. However, when a personality description (data) seems to be very representative of a physics major (e.g., pocket protector) over a biology major, people judge that it is more likely for this person to be a physics major than a natural sciences major (which is a superset of physics). These incorrect appraisals remained even in the face of losing real money in bets on probabilities.

biases.name: Division Fallacy
biases.description: The Division Fallacy is a logical reasoning fallacy wherein statements about a category (e.g., the characteristics of a group of people) are assumed to apply to some or all parts of that category (e.g., to individual people in the group). The assumption can be fallacious either (1) because individuals in a group exhibit variations of traits or behaviors around an average, or (2) because the group exhibits an emergent property that is otherwise exhibited by none of the members individually. See also: Ecological Fallacy.
biases.examples:
For example: "Democrats want higher taxes on the wealthy. John is a Democrat. Therefore, John wants higher taxes on the wealthy." (Perhaps John differs from his fellow Democrats on that particular issue even if Democrats as a group want higher taxes on the wealthy.)

Another example: "Consciousness is something brains do. Brains are made of cells. Therefore, each brain cell must be conscious." (Perhaps consciousness is an emergent property that results from the behavior of a population of brain cells that are each *not* conscious.)

biases.name: Fallacy of Composition
biases.description: The Fallacy of Composition refers to the assumption that something is true of the whole simply because it is true of some part of the whole (or even of every proper part of the whole). See also: Hasty Generalization.
biases.examples:
For example, someone may claim that "Most individual people would be better off if they saved a lot more money. Therefore, if everyone saved a lot more money, we would all be better off."

As another example, regularly practicing mindfulness meditation has been shown in multiple studies to produce mental health benefits, but this does not imply that regular mindfulness meditation would benefit everyone. For instance, some subpopulations with mental health concerns (e.g., dissociative identity disorder) may not experience the benefits that other meditators experience. Those people may then be disappointed or actively harmed in their attempt to start and continue a meditation app aimed at the general population (unless they adapt the behavior and their way of enacting it to suit their particular needs).

For subgroups that differ in meaningful ways from the rest of the population, it may help to recognize those differences. This might help the subpopulation to more realistically plan, think about, enact, and maintain the behavior (perhaps using different strategies from the rest of the population).

biases.name: Forer (or Barnum) Effect
biases.description: The Forer Effect refers to a tendency for people to ascribe high levels of accuracy to a description of their personality that is presented as being tailored to them, despite the fact that it is vague enough to apply to a wide range of people.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 1948, psychologist Bertram R. Forer gave a personality test to his students. He told his students they were each receiving a unique personality analysis that was based on the test's results and to rate their analysis on a scale of 0 (very poor) to 5 (excellent) on how well it applied to themselves. In reality, each received the same analysis. On average, the rating was 4.26, but only after the ratings were turned in was it revealed that each student had received identical copies assembled by Forer from various horoscopes.

biases.examples:
For example, you take a fortune-telling quiz on the internet. The site claims that the results are tailored exactly to you, but actually the site just picks a random fortune out of a list and presents it to you. When you read the fortune, though, it seems like it describes your situation uncannily well. You've fallen prey to the Forer Effect.

As another example, suppose that a health promotion pamphlet is distributed to students at a university, offering ideas for various forms of low-cost aerobic activity for people to try. It contains an anecdote about someone with a busy lifestyle who cares about their studies and loves to socialize. If someone reads this and thinks that the pamphlet seems like it is written for them, they may have fallen prey to the Forer Effect.

biases.name: Gambler's Fallacy
biases.description: Gambler’s Fallacy refers to a belief that, in a series of randomly occurring events, if one event happened less frequently than expected in the recent past, then it is more likely to happen in the future (or vice versa). biases.examples: For example, suppose that someone noticed that they had lost a large sum of money during the previous six months of gambling. They might expect that the next six months should involve *gaining* approximately similar amounts of money to "balance out" the previous losses. They might then conclude that they should not abandon their gambling habit, despite others around them perhaps advising them to do so.

biases.name: Halo Effect
biases.description: The Halo Effect refers to the phenomenon whereby someone’s perception of a person’s (or company’s or product’s) traits is positively influenced by their positive evaluation of other traits belonging to the same person (or company or product).
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 1920, Edward Thorndike asked two commanding officers to evaluate their soldiers in terms of physical qualities (neatness, voice, physique, bearing, and energy), intellect, leadership skills, and personal qualities (including dependability, loyalty, responsibility, selflessness, and cooperation). In Thorndike’s study, attractiveness played an important role in how people tended to consider a person, such as whether an person was friendly or not based on his or her physical appearance. His goal was to see how the ratings of one characteristic affected other characteristics. His study showed how there was too great a correlation in the commanding officers' responses. In his review he stated: "The correlations are too high and too even. For example, for the three raters next studied, the average correlation for physique with intelligence is 0.31; for physique with leadership, 0.39; and for physique with character, 0.28." The ratings of one of the special qualities of an officer often started a trend in the rating results. If an officer had a particular "negative" attribute given off to the commanding officer, it would correlate in the rest of that soldier's results.
biases.examples: For example, someone might assume that a spokesperson who is attractive, svelte, and articulate is therefore an accurate, knowledgeable, and honest source of nutritional information. They might then believe that person because of the Halo Effect, even if the spokesperson is telling them to do something that would be counterproductive.

biases.name: Hindsight Bias
biases.description: Hindsight Bias refers to a tendency to perceive past events as being more predictable than they were before they took place.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 1975, Ruth Beyth and Baruch Fischhoff devised the first experiment directly testing the hindsight bias. They asked participants to judge the likelihood of several outcomes of US president Richard Nixon's upcoming visit to Beijing (then romanized as Peking) and Moscow. Some time after president Nixon's return, participants were asked to recall (or reconstruct) the probabilities they had assigned to each possible outcome, and their perceptions of the likelihood of each outcome was greater or overestimated for events that actually had occurred. This study is frequently referred to in definitions of the hindsight bias, and the title of the paper, "I knew it would happen," may have contributed to the hindsight bias being interchangeable with the phrase "knew-it-all-along phenomenon."

biases.name: Illusion of Control
biases.description: The Illusion of Control refers to a tendency to overestimate the degree to which events fall within one’s control.
biases.experimentalEvidence: To investigate perceptions of control, experimenters may ask people about hypothetical situations, like the likelihood of their involvement in a motor vehicle accident. On average, drivers regard accidents as much less likely in "high-control" situations, such as when they are driving, than in "low-control" situations, such as when they are in the passenger seat. They also rate a high-control accident, such as driving into the car in front, as much less likely than a low-control accident, such as being hit from behind by another driver.
biases.examples: For example, someone who aspires to rapidly increase their activity levels (but who currently lives a sedentary lifestyle) may overestimate the degree to which they have control over whether they will be able to prepare to run a marathon within the next four weeks. They may overlook the fact that they cannot control (1) the fact that it takes longer than four weeks to prepare for a marathon, (2) their physiological responses to their training, (3) their susceptibility to joint overuse and ligamentous strain-related injuries, and so on.

biases.name: Illusory Correlation
biases.description: Illusory Correlation refers to a phenomenon whereby an observer sees a relationship they expected to see between variables in a dataset, even when no such relationship exists.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
David Hamilton and Terrence Rose (1980) found that stereotypes can lead people to expect certain groups and traits to fit together, and they overestimate the frequency of when these correlations actually occur. People overestimate the core association between variables such as stereotyped groups and stereotypic behavior.

Rupert Brown and Amanda Smith (1989) tested the hypothesis by conducting a study involving the academic staff at a British university. The results revealed that the staff had overestimated the number of female seniority staff and underestimated the number of male senior staff. This reflected that the academic staff inaccurately viewed the relationship between gender and seniority, showing that illusory correlations can exist in everyday situations. biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting or avoiding this fallacy:

- Point out when it occurs and encourage the person to notice the uncertainties involved in the situation at hand. Otherwise, the fallacy could cause people to prematurely stop searching for information about how to start and maintain the behavior because they assume they have enough information already. 
- In the longer-term, encourage the person to practice probabilistic thinking, with particular attention being paid to realizing that they should have some uncertainty in every belief that they form. For example, one could note that, although one can be sure that one is currently having thoughts (if one is thinking about this idea, then they must be thinking), this is probably the only thing about which one can really be sure. Beyond that, there is some degree of uncertainty in almost every statement. It might also help to practice fostering epistemic humility. To do this, one could practice (1) realizing that they may be wrong and (2) using evidence and reasoning to routinely subject statements and beliefs to scrutiny (before accepting them).

(Note: the strategies for the Ludic Fallacy are similar to those for Hasty Generalizations.)

  • Take this bias into consideration when presenting costs and benefits of a behavior; one could then plan the delivery of this information accordingly. When presenting costs and benefits, lead with costs. Without downplaying the costs or exaggerating the benefits, show why the benefits outweigh the costs. If possible, absorb some of the costs for users or give additional, non-intrinsic benefits.

biases.name: Observer-Expectancy Effect
biases.description: The Observer-Expectancy Effect (also known as the Experimenter’s Effect or the Expectation Effect) refers to an effect whereby someone expects a particular result (e.g., in an experiment or dataset) and, owing to this expectation, subconsciously manipulates an experiment or misinterprets data in order to find that result.
biases.examples:
For example, a police officer may (subconsciously) believe that black people are morally inferior to white people and may therefore (subconsciously) arrest black people at a higher rate than white people. Later, they might look at their arrest records and notice that they've arrested black people at a higher rate than white people, and they might feel that their worldview is justified (even if they never explicate their own beliefs to themselves). 

As another example, this might manifest in a behavior change context as a person who has an expectation that they'll fail to adopt a new behavior. They may sabotage themselves or misinterpret the actual outcomes as manifestations of failure.

biases.name: Omission Bias
biases.description: Omission Bias refers to a tendency to judge harmful actions as morally worse than equally harmful omissions (inactions). (Note that some moral philosophers posit that this is not a bias and that it truly is the case that harmful actions are morally worse than harmful omissions; i.e., they endorse the acts / omissions distinction. And, since some moral theories assign weight to intentions instead of or in addition to outcomes, there may be a useful distinction to be made between intentional and accidental omissions when judging the value of an omission.)
biases.experimentalEvidence: Spranca, Minsk, and Baron extended the omission bias to judgments of morality of choices. In one scenario, John, a tennis player, would be facing a tough opponent the next day in a decisive match. John knows that his opponent is allergic to a food substance. Subjects were presented with two conditions: John recommends the food containing the allergen to hurt his opponent's performance, or the opponent himself orders the allergenic food, and John says nothing. A majority of people judged that John's action of recommending the allergenic food as being more immoral than John's inaction of not informing the opponent of the allergenic substance.

biases.name: Optimism Bias
biases.description: Optimism Bias is the tendency to be unduly optimistic about the probability of future positive and negative events (i.e., overestimating the probability of the former while underestimating the probability of the latter).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Armor and Taylor review a number of studies that have found optimism bias in different kinds of judgment. These include:---Second-year MBA students overestimated the number of job offers they would receive and their starting salary;---Students overestimated the scores they would achieve on exams;---Almost all newlyweds in a US study expected their marriage to last a lifetime, even while aware of divorce statistics;---Professional financial analysts consistently overestimated corporate earnings;---Most smokers believe they are less at risk of developing smoking-related diseases than others who smoke. Companies have exploited this bias by increasing interest rates to punitive rates for any late payment, knowing that overconfidence causes many people to grossly underestimate their odds of making a payment late.

biases.experimentalEvidence:
[taken from original description column as these appear less about definitions and more about more in-depth explanations] Pareidolia refers to a phenomenon whereby vague and/or random stimuli are perceived as significant, e.g., seeing images of animals or faces in clouds, the man in the moon, and hearing hidden messages on records played in reverse.

Pareidolia is why we find a "face" when we look at two dots and a line arranged inside of a circle.

Carl Sagan hypothesized that as a survival technique, human beings are "hard-wired" from birth to identify the human face. This allows people to use only minimal details to recognize faces from a distance and in poor visibility, but can also lead them to interpret random images or patterns of light and shade as being faces. The evolutionary advantages of being able to identify friend from foe with split-second accuracy are numerous. For example, prehistoric (and even modern) men and women who accidentally identify an enemy as a friend could face deadly consequences for this mistake. This is only one among many evolutionary pressures responsible for the development of the modern facial recognition capability of modern humans

biases.name: Pseudocertainty Effect
biases.description: The Pseudocertainty Effect refers to a tendency to perceive an outcome as certain despite uncertainty in multi-stage decision-making.
biases.examples: For example, someone may have the goal of mastering as much of a new skill as they can by a specific date and might be deciding whether to apply for one of two difficult-to-enter courses teaching that skill. They might only have a 25% chance of gaining entry to either of the options, but they need to decide in advance which of the two they want to apply for: a strictly-structured course or a self-paced one (that would allow them to learn 1.5 times as much material overall). Suppose they believe that by doing the strictly-structured one, they can be ~100% sure to learn the skill by a specific date; on the other hand, they predict only an 80% chance of engaging in the course material associated with the alternative, self-paced course. If they fell prey to the Pseudocertainty Effect, they would opt for the strictly-structured course (which offers ~100% certainty of covering some material) even though the self-paced course actually has a higher expected value (80% certainty of covering 1.5 times as much material means that we could expect to cover 120% of the material in the unstructured compared to in the structured course, on average).

biases.experimentalEvidence: [first two sentences here are taken from description column: There are four important elements to reactance theory: perceived freedom, threat to freedom, reactance, and restoration of freedom. Freedom is not an abstract consideration, but rather a feeling associated with real behaviors, including actions, emotions, and attitudes. ] One study concluded that one way to increase the activity of a threatened freedom is to censor it, or provide a threatening message toward the activity. In turn a "boomerang effect" occurs, in which people choose forbidden alternatives. This study also shows that social influence has better results when it does not threaten one's core freedoms. Two concepts revealed in this study are that a communicator may be able to increase the positive force toward compliance by increasing his or her credibility, and that increasing the positive communication force and decreasing the negative communication force simultaneously should increase compliance.

Reactance refers to an emotional reaction in direct contradiction to imposed rules that are perceived to threaten one’s behavioral freedoms. Such a reaction can cause people to adopt or strengthen views that contradict the imposed rules.

For example, many people appear to have directly contradicted public health advice and rules regarding mask-wearing (to reduce the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus).

Ideas for avoiding this phenomenon:

  • Ask a trusted community-member to communicate behavioral change goals or requests.
  • Frame communication in the most positive way possible.
  • Appeal to people’s already-held values to encourage adoption of the new behavior.

biases.name: Status Quo Bias
biases.description: Status Quo Bias refers to a cognitive bias favoring the maintenance of the current state of affairs (i.e., the status quo) over alternative options (i.e., over departures from the status quo).
biases.experimentalEvidence: The US states of New Jersey and Pennsylvania inadvertently ran a real life experiment providing evidence of the Status Quo Bias in the early 1990s. As part of Tort law reform programs, citizens were offered two options for their automotive insurance: an expensive option giving them full right to sue, and a less expensive option with restricted rights to sue. In New Jersey the cheaper option was the default and most citizens selected it, while only a minority chose it in Pennsylvania where the more expensive option was the default. Similar effects have been shown for contributions to retirement plans, choice of internet privacy policies and the decision to become an organ donor.

- Learn about or encourage others to learn about the negative social impacts of Stereotyping.

biases.name: Straw Man Fallacy
biases.description: The Straw Man Fallacy is the strategy of responding to a weak version of an opponent’s position, that they don’t actually believe, rather than responding to the opponent’s original position (which may have been more difficult to refute).
biases.examples: For example, someone may argue that their chronically tired friend should aim to sleep more than 6 hours per night, and the friend may respond by saying, "I can't sleep all day---I have things to do!" (This would represent a response to a very weak version of the argument (that the person should sleep all day), rather than the original argument, which was simply that they should try sleeping more than 6 hours a night.)

Ideas for counteracting fallacy:

- Base your approach to the situation on how strongly the person holds their opposing beliefs. 
- If the person holds their beliefs strongly, then try the strategies for Wishful Thinking and the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy. 
- If the person doesn't hold their beliefs too strongly to engage in productive discussion, encourage them to practice actively considering the reasons that arguments in opposition to their own could actually turn out to be true. - Foster epistemic / intellectual humility. biases.name: Subjective Validation
biases.description: Subjective Validation refers to someone’s perception that a statement is true merely because it has personal meaning or significance to them.
biases.examples:
For example, a woman who has been sexually harassed in the workplace might believe the statement "Most women are sexually harassed in the workplace" merely because she's had personal experience with sexual harassment. (The statement might still be true, but the belief that it's true should be a conclusion drawn from the statistical analysis of evidence and not based on mere personal (i.e., anecdotal) experience.)

For example, a person might believe the claim that "everything happens for a reason" because a deceased loved one used to say it all the time, and believing it provides both a way of making sense of the loved one's death and a way of honoring their memory.

biases.name: Thinking in Categories / Binary Thinking

When someone conceptualizes a concept as being composed of only two categories (e.g., “good” or “bad,” or “right” or “wrong”), this can also be called Binary Thinking. (These kinds of thinking are simpler than continuum thinking, wherein concepts are conceptualized as occurring on a continuum.)

biases.name: Ultimate Attribution Error
biases.description: Ultimate Attribution Error refers to an error whereby someone attributes an outgroup’s negative behavior to internal causes like personality traits and positive behavior to external causes—yet they attribute an ingroup’s positive behavior to internal causes and negative behavior to external causes.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In his 1976 demonstration, Birt Duncan asked White participants to watch a video of a man shoving another man. One video had a Caucasian male shoving another Caucasian male and a second video had an African American male shoving a Caucasian male. When the participants watched the first video they concluded that the Caucasian male doing the shoving was attributed to having fun (a situational factor), but when they watched the second video they attributed the African American’s behavior to an aggressive personality (Duncan, 1979). The results of Duncan's study demonstrates that ultimate attribution error is more likely to occur when there are negative associations with members of an outgroup due to previous conflict or certain situations that were experienced (Whitley & Kite, 2010).

If the person bringing the food was an ingroup member, the observer might attribute the action to internal causes (e.g., agreeableness, generosity, conscientiousness, culinary skills, etc.).

biases.name: Zero-Risk Bias
biases.description: Zero-risk Bias refers to the cognitive bias favoring opportunities to eliminate rather than mitigate risk. This can become relevant when there are multiple possible courses of action, some of which involve complete elimination of a subcategory of risk and others of which do not. This bias can cause people to irrationally favor options that completely eliminate a subcategory of risk, even if other options come with a greater absolute reduction in risk overall.
biases.experimentalEvidence: This bias has been demonstrated in multiple studies, with its probability of affecting decision-making appearing to depend on the decision-making context and framing (e.g., [Schneider et al., 2017](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2017-30652-004?casa_token=DoeNW5Pr_h4AAAAA:x2ARETOKfbu36oNRrcd8dgznUGeHhOi5y-XfpqkBuHZ6Ijq7OZy0sUZsk_onyEH3B1idwdM36R9yEdr8XN81p_6F); [Raue & Schneider, 2019](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-11456-5_5)). In one recent study ([Cantarelli, Belle & Belardinelli, 2020](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0734371X18778090?casa_token=SuOajn6vVvgAAAAA%3A-f8cxnU1B4lplrwGne2UrBwLTS6UVgwcmN1kd3J6UimijTGMaq-ZvuzOcmlwIda0g7QXQiw4KPUhuA)), 495 nurses were given a scenario where they were told that an infectious disease had broken out in two developing countries, and that the doses of the perfectly effective vaccination were limited. One intervention plan would save an expected 6,000 lives via partial vaccination coverage in both nations: this plan would reduce deaths from 8,000 to 4,000 in one country and from 4,000 to 2,000 in the other country. The other intervention plan would save an expected 5,000 lives, but entailed a full vaccination coverage in one nation (from 4,000 to 0 deaths, so zero risk of death from that disease in that country) and a partial vaccination coverage in the other nation (from 8,000 to 7,000 in that country). Approximately 29% of the sample appeared to be affected by zero-risk bias, favoring the scenario that involved complete elimination of risk in one of the countries, despite that option saving 1,000 fewer lives overall.

biases.examples: For example, someone who is attempting to decrease the environmental harms associated with their lifestyle might focus on completely eliminating their use of plastic straws (because this would reduce their production of plastic straw waste to zero) while neglecting other actions that they could take to reduce the harm they produce to a much greater degree (even though risks in other categories couldn't be reduced to zero, and might not be able to be estimated precisely).

biases.ideasForTesting: Imagine that you suffer from terrible migraine headaches, and you have a choice of taking one of two new medicines, Medicine A or Medicine B, both of which will completely eliminate your migraines. However, Medicine A has causes side effect X in 1 out of every 25 people and side effect Y in 1 out of every 10 people, though it can never cause both side effects in one person. Medicine B causes side effect X in 1 out of every 5 people, but does not cause side effect Y in anyone. Assuming that you believe side effects X and Y to be equally undesirable, which medicine do you take?
biases.evenMoreNotes: If I did the math correctly, there is a 13.6% chance of experiencing a side effect with medicine A, and a 20% chance of experiencing a side effect with medicine B. I'm not confident that this question would test the zero-risk bias as much as one's (in)ability to properly compute probabilities.
biases.content:
Zero-risk Bias refers to the cognitive bias favoring opportunities to eliminate rather than mitigate risk. This can become relevant when there are multiple possible courses of action, some of which involve complete elimination of a subcategory of risk and others of which do not. This bias can cause people to irrationally favor options that completely eliminate a subcategory of risk, even if other options come with a greater absolute reduction in risk overall.

For example, someone who is attempting to decrease the environmental harms associated with their lifestyle might focus on completely eliminating their use of plastic straws (because this would reduce their production of plastic straw waste to zero) while neglecting other actions that they could take to reduce the harm they produce to a much greater degree (even though risks in other categories couldn’t be reduced to zero, and might not be able to be estimated precisely).

Ideas for counteracting this bias:

  • Point it out when you see someone being affected by it and encourage the person to reevaluate the situation.
  • Write down the estimated risks associated with each of the possible outcomes / choices being considered, along with the predicted risks following different actions.
  • Over the longer term, practice probabilistic reasoning.
biases.title: Zero-Risk Bias

examples.description: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...the advertisement she saw hadn't mentioned the potentially life-changing benefits of therapy for anxiety.
Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...a friend hadn't described to him the suffering of animals and the environmental damage caused by factory farming.

Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't realized that her behavior was inconsistent; she went into this line of work to help the world, so why would she put it at risk by publishing potentially dangerous research on how to make viruses more virulent?

substeps.title: 3. Intends to engage in the behavior
substeps.description:
Even if we desire adopting a new behavior, we're very unlikely to actually do so unless we ourselves predict that we will conduct that behavior at specific times, in specific situations, or within a certain time frame. There are a variety of reasons we may not intend to engage in a behavior even when we find the behavior desirable:
  1. Busyness—e.g., we may think "I don't have time in my life right now to start a behavior like this"
  2. Delay—e.g., we may think "I'll get around to doing this eventually"
  3. Lack of Self-Efficacy—e.g., we may think "I'll probably fail if I try to engage in this behavior"
  4. Ambiguity—e.g., we may think "I don't know how to get started"
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't made a plan to search online therapist directories right after work that evening.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't decided that, from that moment forward, he wouldn't eat meat again.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't decided that, from then on, each time she had a new project idea she would consider its societal risks before committing to it.
substeps.question: How can you help the target person or population to anticipate or to plan to adopt the target behavior during a given time frame or whenever they are in a specific context?

biases.name: Actor-Observer Asymmetry
biases.description: The Actor-Observer Asymmetry occurs when people subconsciously attribute behavior to different causes depending on whether they’re the person performing the behavior (the actor) or merely a witness (an observer). When assessing their own behavior as actors, people tend to emphasize the influence of the situation on their behavior and downplay the influence of their own personality or character. When assessing others’ behavior as observers, the reverse is true: people’s assessment of others’ behavior tends to emphasize the influence of personality or character on the behavior and downplay the influence of the situation. See also: Fundamental Attribution Error.
biases.experimentalEvidence: This has been demonstrated in studies by differentiating between actors' and observers' explanations in the following way: people's explanations were separated into theoretically meaningful distinctions (e.g., reasons vs. causal history of reason explanations). The responses were categorized, and the differences emerged.
biases.examples: For example: "I haven't been able to get into the habit of going to the gym because life has just been so busy lately. Every day, I go to work, come home and spend a few minutes with my kids and spouse, cook dinner, and work on remodeling our back porch. I don't have time to go to the gym! But I'm totally unlike my spouse: they avoid the gym out of pure laziness."
biases.automaticKeywords: actor, agent, assassin, astronomer, asymmetry, fractals, luminosity, observer, philosopher, physicist, scholar, symmetry
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this bias:

- Ask people to consider how a friend, loved one, or ideal person would have behaved in the same situation. 
- When possible, ask people to compare their actions against other people in identical situations. They might see that the context was less relevant than they supposed and that their character was more relevant than they realized. For example, if a person skipped gym day because of a thunderstorm that day, ask them whether or not their gym buddy also missed that day because of the storm.

biases.name: Affirming the Consequent Fallacy
biases.description: This fallacy has the form: “If P, then Q. Q. Therefore P.” The mistake lies in the assumption that if P implies Q, then Q implies P.
biases.examples: For example: "Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."

Idea for counteracting this fallacy:

- Show that there are other ways to arrive at the current state of affairs by giving concrete counterexamples. In the example above ("Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."), it's possible that Alice has gotten fit through some other means than Crossfit; perhaps she does P90X, for example.

biases.name: Ambiguity Effect
biases.description: The Ambiguity Effect is a cognitive bias wherein decision-makers tend to select options for which the probability of a favorable outcome is known instead of an option for which the probability of a favorable outcome is unknown or ambiguous.
biases.examples:
For example: "I know that if I pick Door #1, I have a 15% chance of winning a moderately good prize. I also know that if I pick Door #2, I'll win a prize, but I don't know how good the prize will be or what the chances of winning are. I guess I'll pick Door #1!"

Another example: "I want to invest in Company #1 because it has a proven track record of success...even though that investment will have a low ROI and I'm not absolutely in love with their product. I'd rather do that than invest in Company #2 because, even though Company #2 has a product I like, I just don't know anything about them!"

Another example: Someone might choose a fixed-rate mortgage (where the interest rate doesn't change) over a variable-rate mortgage (where the interest rate fluctuates with the market) even if the variable-rate mortgage saves them money.

biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this effect:

- Report the likelihood of all outcomes wherever possible. 
- Develop an intuition for the probabilities by comparing them to commonly-known outcomes.

biases.name: Denying the Antecedent Fallacy
biases.description: Denying the Antecedent Fallacy is a logical fallacy about the relationships between categories or assertions. It takes the form: “If P, then Q. Not P. Therefore, not Q.” The fallacy is the assumption that the conclusion follows from the premises, although it actually doesn’t follow (e.g., because there can be cases of Q that are not preceded by P). The fact that Q always follows if P is true does not imply that Q must always be preceded by P.
biases.examples: For example, "If you go to the gym, you'll get fit. You don't go to the gym, so you can't possibly get fit!"
biases.automaticKeywords: after, analogy, antecedent, axiomatic, deny, hadith, hypothesis, motive, premise, refutation, subjective, syllogism, theism
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

- Point it out and to show why it is a fallacy. By pointing out the flaw in this reasoning, you could open up a more comprehensive range of possible plans that the person could form (e.g., to meet their behavioral goals). 
- Provide counterexamples to show that (to use the example from above) it's possible to get fit *without* going to the gym.

biases.name: Fallacy of the Single Cause
biases.description: The Fallacy of the Single Cause refers to a fallacious assumption that there is a single cause of an outcome (whereas in reality, the outcome may instead be attributable to a number of only jointly sufficient causes).
biases.examples: For example, suppose that someone was overweight and decided to work toward returning to a healthy weight range by engaging in regular physical activity, consulting with a dietician, and adjusting their caloric intake over a two-year period. And suppose that these changes were jointly sufficient for the person to return to a healthy weight range. Their friend might attribute this change to the person's physical activity alone, without realizing that it was due to several jointly sufficient causes.

biases.automaticKeywords: ascribe, attribute, attributed, cause, causes, factor, factors, many, multiple, outcome, result, single, subjective
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

- It might help to point out the flawed reasoning. One way to do this might be by sharing evidence demonstrating that the phenomenon in question would not have happened if some of the jointly sufficient causes were not present. 
- Noting when this fallacy is occurring could be particularly helpful at various stages of behavioral change. For example, someone may need assistance forming realistic plans to start the behavior, forming realistic expectations about the effects of the behavior and its advantages over alternative behaviors, or understanding the sufficient conditions for maintenance of the behavior. 
- Questioning one's assumptions and developing a better understanding of the sufficient causes of specific outcomes might help with forming more realistic plans, which should increase the chances of successfully starting and maintaining the behavior in question.

biases.name: False Analogy Fallacy
biases.description: The False Analogy Fallacy refers to a fallacious assumption that if two things are similar in some ways, and if one of those things has a certain property, then the other thing will also have that property. It has the following form: “A and B are similar in some ways. A has property X; therefore, B has property X.” If B does not have property X, then this represents an example of the False Analogy Fallacy.
biases.examples: For example, suppose that Alice observes that Bob has decided to engage in the same spin class as her. After they talk, it becomes apparent that both of them value fitness and have chosen to increase their activity levels. Alice might then assume that because they have some things in common, she will automatically have other characteristics in common with Bob (e.g., she may assume they both need to meet the goal in the same way and will run into the same challenges).

- It might also help to form a more realistic appraisal of the situation in question via the collection of information from a wider range of (non-anecdotal) sources. This might then facilitate more realistic plans for commencing and continuing the behavior.

biases.name: Overconfidence Effect
biases.description: The Overconfidence Effect refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone’s confidence in their answers to questions exceeds their level of accuracy. See also: Dunning-Kruger Effect.
biases.experimentalEvidence: The Overconfidence Effect is one of the most important and well-studied cognitive biases in psychology and behavioral economics. Overconfidence has been studied in three different ways: 1. Overestimation of one's performance, ability, level of control, or rate of work; 2. An inflated belief that one is better than others, or overplacement; and 3. An excessive belief in the truth and accuracy of one’s beliefs, or overprecision. One is example is shown in a spelling task, where subjects were correct about 80% of the time when they were "100% certain." Put another way, the error rate was 20% when subjects expected it to be 0%.

biases.name: Trait Ascription Bias
biases.description: Trait Ascription Bias is a bias wherein people view themselves as relatively variable in terms of personality, behavior, and mood, despite viewing others as much more predictable. It has been hypothesized that this may arise because our own internal states are directly observable and available to us (which is, of course, not the case for others’ mental states).

However, they may believe that the effects they experience following the behavior will be less predictable, owing to their (seemingly) more complex and varying range of affective states.

biases.name: Attentional Bias
biases.description: Attentional Bias occurs when some information or evidence holds a disproportionate amount of a person’s attention because of that person’s environment or history.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In studies using the dot-probe paradigm, patients who suffered from chronic ailments such as anxiety were more likely to focus on information or stimuli representing their concerns (e.g., in the case of anxiety, patients were more likely to focus on worried facial expressions).

A within-subjects bias occurs when an individual displays greater bias toward one type of information (e.g., painful faces) when compared to different types of information (e.g., neutral faces). Alternatively, a between-subjects bias occurs when one group of participants displays greater bias than another group of participants (e.g., chronic pain patients showed greater bias towards painful expressions than did healthy control participants).

For example, someone might be worried that their friend is angry with them, so they may pay extra close attention to the friend's facial expressions, looking for signs of annoyance. Because they don't consider how often these expressions normally occur, though, they may end up picking up on normal signals and viewing them as abnormal, believing this confirms their hypothesis.

As another example, someone may only focus on what could go wrong in a situation, less often considering what could go right or how things are likely to go. They may worry a lot, reducing their overall quality of life and preoccupying their mind with unnecessary worries.

biases.name: Context Effect in Memory
biases.description: Context-dependent memory refers to improved retrieval (or recall) of specific memories if the context present at the time of memory retrieval is the same as the context present at the time the memory was first stored (or encoded).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Psychologists that have researched context dependent recall include Abernathy (1940), as well as Godden & Baddeley (1975). Context-dependent cues are dependent on the environment and situation. Memory retrieval can be facilitated or triggered by replication of the context in which the memory was encoded. Such conditions include weather, company, location, smelling a particular odor, hearing a certain song, and even taste can sometimes act as a cue. For example, students sometimes fail to recall diligently studied material when an examination room's environmental conditions differ significantly from the room or place where learning occurred. To improve learning and recall, it is recommended that students should study under conditions that closely resemble an examination.

biases.name: Generation Effect in Memory
biases.description: The Generation Effect refers to a cognitive phenomenon whereby people are more likely to remember information if they generate it than if they only read it.
biases.experimentalEvidence: The generation effect is typically achieved in cognitive psychology experiments by asking participants to generate words from word fragments. This effect has also been demonstrated using a variety of other materials, such as when generating a word after being presented with its antonym or synonym, generating keywords in paragraphs, pictures, and arithmetic problems. In addition, the generation effect has been found in studies using free recall, cued recall, and recognition tests. In one study, the subject was provided with a stimulus word, the first letter of the response, and a word relating the two. For example, with the rule of opposite, the stimulus word "hot", and the letter "c", the word "cold" would be generated. This methodology has since been used in the majority of experiments investigating the generation effect.
biases.examples: For example, you may be more likely to remember the word "orangutan" if you generate it from the fragment "or_ng_ta_" than if you simply see the word in its entirety.
biases.automaticKeywords: dwell, erase, forget, generate, memories, memory, remember, remembering, rewind, underestimate
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for leveraging this bias:

- Encourage people to come to conclusions for themselves instead of handing them a fully-formed train of thought. For example, you could inspire someone to start giving to charity by asking them questions that challenge them to think about their values and about ways in which they are (or aren't) aligning their actions with those values. 
- You could also ask people to develop mnemonic devices or personalized memory aids to help with their behavior change efforts. For example, suppose someone is trying to manage their anger. They might be more likely to remember this goal if they generate their own acronym (e.g., "CAT," for "Controlling Anger Today") than if you provide them with a pre-made acronym. (They could then recite this to themself, or could put their acronym somewhere they'll see it often.)

We're very unlikely to attempt a specific action if we don't think that attempting it will help us to achieve a desired outcome. We may fail to believe that attempting an action will help us achieve a desired outcome for various reasons:

biases.name: Base Rate Neglect
biases.description: Base Rate Neglect, or Base Rate Fallacy or Bias, is an error that occurs when the conditional probability of some hypothesis H, given some evidence E, is assessed without taking into account the “base rate” or “prior probability” of H and the total probability of evidence E.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In some experiments, students were asked to estimate the grade point averages (GPAs) of hypothetical students. When given relevant statistics about GPA distribution, students tended to ignore them if given descriptive information about the particular student, even if the new descriptive information was obviously of little or no relevance to school performance. 

Psychologists attempted to explain this finding in terms of the Representativeness Heuristic. Others have argued that some attributional biases like the Fundamental Attribution Error are instances of the Base Rate Fallacy: people underutilize "consensus information" (the "base rate") about how others behaved in similar situations and instead prefer simpler dispositional attributions.
biases.automaticKeywords: correlation, likelihood, likely, placebo, possibility, prior, probabilities, probability, probable, risk, statistically
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this effect:

- Support people to increase their weighting of background or contextual information in a given situation.
- Develop an intuitive understanding of how to use background information by watching [this explainer video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lG4VkPoG3ko). 
- Use examples like the ones below to help people develop an understanding of the importance of background information. You don't necessarily have to bring math into it (as in Example #1), but it's still useful to help people find ways to evaluate their scenario-specific information relative to the broader context (as in Example #2).

Example #1: It is known that 1 in 10,000 people have a certain kind of cancer. It is also known that the test for that cancer is 99% accurate: if applied to someone who has the cancer it will be correct 99% of the time, and if applied to someone who doesn't have the cancer it will also be correct 99% of the time. If a doctor performs the test (as a random screening) on a patient, and the test says they have the cancer, how likely is it that they really do? If the doctor just takes into consideration the accuracy of the test, then they might conclude that the patient is 99% likely to have the cancer. But this neglects the fact that very few people have the cancer (that is, the base rate of the cancer is low). Out of 10,000 randomly selected people, only 1 of them, on average, will have the cancer. But the test will claim that about 100 more people will have the cancer (since it is 99% accurate, so it will be wrong 1% of the time). Hence, of the 101 people it says has the cancer, only one of them really has it, so the randomly selected patient who tested positive only has a 1/101 (about 1%) chance of having the cancer, not a 99% chance like the doctor thought! This shows that evidence has to be combined with the base rate information (what you believed before you got the new evidence) to figure out how likely something is.

Example #2: It is known that only a very small percentage of startups last longer than two years. Someone might be considering investing in a startup that seems to have been doing well during the two months that it has been running. They may be so impressed with the startup team that they are sure that it'll last longer than two years. However, this confidence is likely to be misplaced given the background information that most startups fail.
biases.ideasForTesting:
Provide person with statistics about number of people in U.S. living with HIV and the chances of a false positive on an HIV test. Then ask the % chance that a randomly selected person in the U.S. has HIV if he/she tests positive. 

Can we make a more real world type example out of the same problem?

biases.name: Belief Bias
biases.description: Belief Bias refers to a tendency to base one’s degree of support for a set of arguments on the perceived believability of the conclusion, rather than how strongly the presented arguments support that conclusion.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In a series of experiments, subjects were presented with deductive arguments (in each of which a series of premises and a conclusion are given) and asked to indicate if each conclusion necessarily follows from the premises given. In other words, the subjects are asked to make an evaluation of logical validity. The subjects, however, exhibited belief bias when they rejected valid arguments with unbelievable conclusions, and endorsed invalid arguments with believable conclusions. It seems that instead of following directions and assessing logical validity, the subjects based their assessments on personal beliefs.

- Show people that the conclusions from experiments or arguments are not always intuitive or even believable by providing examples from history. biases.content:
The Clustering Illusion refers to a tendency to see patterns or clusters in samples drawn from random distributions.

For example, a person might think they notice that they tend to win more at a casino when wearing a certain tie, so they choose to wear a tie the next time they go to the casino, and they end up losing a lot of money.

Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

  • Show examples of people inaccurately finding patterns where they don’t exist.
  • Remember that pattern identification is nothing more than an intuition unless a clear causal link can be established (or the pattern is unlikely enough to be due to chance that the possibility it is due to random variation can be ruled out).

biases.name: Confirmation Bias
biases.description: Confirmation Bias refers to a tendency for people to favor information that confirms their preconceptions or hypotheses (even if the information isn’t true).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Experiments have repeatedly found that people tend to test hypotheses in a one-sided way: by searching for evidence consistent with the hypothesis they have formed at a given time. Confirmation biases are not limited to the collection of evidence. Although two individuals may have the same information, the way they interpret it can be biased. Even if someone has sought and interpreted evidence in a neutral manner, he or she may still remember it selectively to reinforce his/her expectations. So, the Confirmation Bias may operate at three different stages: when gathering evidence, when analyzing the evidence, or when remembering the evidence.

biases.name: Congruence Bias
biases.description: Congruence Bias refers to a tendency for people to test a given hypothesis by trying to directly test it rather than testing alternative hypotheses.
biases.examples: For example, someone might believe that their current diet is the only one they could enjoy and might think that they would be incapable of abstaining from the five soft drinks they have every day. They might directly test and confirm the relationship between their happiness and their diet by repeatedly noticing how happy they feel when they have their soft drinks, but they might be overlooking the fact that they haven't ever tested a key alternative hypothesis: namely, that it might be possible to enjoy other, more nutritious diets.

biases.name: Pessimism Bias
biases.description: Pessimism bias refers to a tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative occurrences.
biases.automaticKeywords: anxiety, depression, estimate, forecast, negative, outlook, pessimism, probabilities, probability, skepticism, uncertainty
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this effect:

- Clearly explain the probability of success.
- Encourage the person to consider the evidence that might count against their pessimistic conclusions. 
- Help the person to document, celebrate, and remember each successful step towards behavior change (even the small ones---and especially the ones that they did not predict would be possible). If it is not overcome, pessimism bias could negatively affect someone's chances of behavior change at every stage (from the planning through to implementation and maintenance of the behavior). It could also cause a person to form unrealistic underestimates of their abilities, which might distort their reasoning about the best ways of implementing and continuing the behavior or might give them the impression that some behavior change goals or steps could be unattainable for them. 

Idea for leveraging this effect:

- Be pessimistic enough to plan ahead for setbacks but not so pessimistic that you are discouraged from forming or implementing plans in the first place.

biases.name: Subadditivity Effect

biases.experimentalEvidence: For instance, subjects in one experiment judged that the probability of death from cancer in the United States was 18%, the probability from heart attack was 22%, and the probability of death from "other natural causes" was 33%. Natural causes are made up precisely of cancer, heart attack, and "other natural causes," however, the sum of the latter three probabilities was 73%, and not 58%. substeps.title: 6. Chooses to perform each action instead of other available actions
substeps.description:
Even if we remember to perform an action, we're very unlikely to perform that action unless we choose it over the other actions or opportunities that are available to us at the same time. There are various reasons why we may not choose to do an action, even if we've remembered we are supposed to do it:
  1. Temptation—e.g., we may think "It would be more fun and relaxing to watch TV instead"
  2. Unpleasantness—e.g., we may avoid an action because it is unappealing or because we believe it will be unpleasant to carry out
  3. Distraction—e.g., we may start the action but get distracted in the middle by something else
  4. Opportunity Cost—e.g., we may think "It's more important that I do this other thing right now"
  5. Time—e.g., we may think "I don't have enough time to complete this action right now"
  6. Anxiety—e.g., we may feel stressed about the idea of trying to carry out the action, and so avoid attempting it
  7. Confusion—e.g., we may feel uncertainty about how to start the action, and so not start it at all

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY:: The further out into the future that benefits or costs will be accrued or incurred, the less people care about them. So benefits in one minute are valued more than benefits tomorrow, which are valued more than benefits in one year. One type of discounting is hyperbolic discounting, according to which how much people care about future benefits "fall relatively rapidly for earlier delay periods (as in, from now to one week), but then fall more slowly for longer delay periods (for instance, more than a few days). For example, in a study subjects said they would be indifferent between receiving $15 immediately or $30 after 3 months, $60 after 1 year, or $100 after 3 years. These indifferences reflect annual discount rates that declined from 277% to 139% to 63% as delays got longer. This contrasts with exponential discounting, in which valuation falls by a constant factor per unit delay and the discount rate stays the same." Another effect of hyperbolic discounting is that "many people prefer $100 now to $110 in a day, but very few people prefer $100 in 30 days to $110 in 31 days." In other words: "More generally, the rate at which people discount future rewards declines as the length of the delay increases". When the intrinsic benefit of the behavior change is delayed in time (for example, if a person is trying to lose weight the goal will take at least months to be met), people are more likely to choose to not perform the desired action for the immediate pleasure / reward (eating a bowl of ice cream) because of excessively high rates of discounting, so interventions to address this have to make the delayed reward more desirable or build in immediate rewards (e.g., marking one more day of eating healthy on a tracker).

biases.name: Distinction Bias
biases.description: Distinction Bias refers to a tendency to view two options as more dissimilar to each other when they are simultaneously evaluated than when they are separately evaluated.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Research shows that options presented simultaneously are evaluated differently than the same options presented separately. For example, when televisions are displayed next to each other on the sales floor, the difference in quality between two very similar, high-quality televisions may appear great. A consumer may pay a much higher price for the higher-quality television, even though the difference in quality is imperceptible when the televisions are viewed in isolation.
biases.wasEvidenceCopypastedFromSomewhereIfSoHa: This would need rewording. Depending on the level of depth we want to go into when explaining the evidence supporting the existence of particular biases, I would feel the need to go and find the actual studies before describing and citing them. :S Currently, though, this comes from http://nlpnotes.com/distinction-bias/
biases.examples: For example, someone may agonize over a decision between two very similar gyms (that have minor differences in price, equipment, bathroom facilities, opening hours, and levels of convenience). Even if the differences have little practical relevance, the differences between the two options may appear more pronounced while the person is evaluating them together than if the person were to evaluate the desirability of the two options separately.

biases.benevolentHelper:
Idea for counteracting this bias:

- Remind people that merely beginning a new, positive behavior may be more important than perfecting the actual implementation details. For example, going to the gym at all is much more important than choosing the right gym with 100% certainty, so flipping a coin to make the decision might enable the person to make a quick choice and begin their new exercise routine without getting hung up on comparing gyms.

Idea for leveraging this bias:

- One could bring the old behavior and the new behavior into contrast, exploring the pros and cons of each. Otherwise, people may not think of the behaviors as competing with each other (and thus may not compare them to each other), or they may think that the behaviors are similar enough that choosing one over the other doesn't matter very much.

Distinction Bias refers to a tendency to view two options as more dissimilar to each other when they are simultaneously evaluated than when they are separately evaluated.

For example, someone may agonize over a decision between two very similar gyms (that have minor differences in price, equipment, bathroom facilities, opening hours, and levels of convenience). Even if the differences have little practical relevance, the differences between the two options may appear more pronounced while the person is evaluating them together than if the person were to evaluate the desirability of the two options separately.

Idea for counteracting this bias:

  • Remind people that merely beginning a new, positive behavior may be more important than perfecting the actual implementation details. For example, going to the gym at all is much more important than choosing the right gym with 100% certainty, so flipping a coin to make the decision might enable the person to make a quick choice and begin their new exercise routine without getting hung up on comparing gyms.

Idea for leveraging this bias:

  • One could bring the old behavior and the new behavior into contrast, exploring the pros and cons of each. Otherwise, people may not think of the behaviors as competing with each other (and thus may not compare them to each other), or they may think that the behaviors are similar enough that choosing one over the other doesn’t matter very much.

biases.name: Loss Aversion
biases.description: Loss Aversion refers to people’s tendency to prefer avoiding losses to acquiring gains.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Recent studies have questioned the existence of loss aversion. One found that loss aversion does not exist in small payoff magnitudes. Another found that loss aversion is more likely to affect a person in competitive situations. [next sentences are taken from the old version of the description column:] Some studies suggest that losses are twice as powerful, psychologically, as gains. Whether a transaction is framed as a loss or a gain is very important: would you rather get a $5 discount (win), or avoid a $5 surcharge (loss)? The same change in price framed differently has a significant effect on consumer behavior. In other words, losses have a more profound effect on us than does a gain of the same value. This is related to the Endowment Effect, and was once thought to be an consequence of it.

biases.examples: For example, consider two groups of people. In Group A, people are told that they will receive $100 at the end of the week if they exercise every day. In Group B, people are given $100 at the beginning of the week and told that they will lose that money at the end of the week if they don't exercise every day. All other things being equal, Group B will be more likely to succeed in exercising every day because their motivation to avoid losing the money will be stronger than Group A's motivation to acquire the money.

biases.description: Unit Bias refers to a preference for finishing a given unit of a task or an item.

biases.name: Dunning–Kruger Effect
biases.description: The Dunning-Kruger Effect refers to a phenomenon in which people who are less adept at a particular skill appear to overestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory superiority), while those who are more highly skilled appear to underestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory inferiority).
biases.experimentalEvidence:
Dunning and Kruger concluded, "across four studies, the authors found that participants scoring in the bottom quartile on tests of humor, grammar, and logic grossly overestimated their test performance and ability. Although test scores put them in the 12th percentile, they estimated themselves to be in the 62nd." Meanwhile, people with true ability tended to underestimate their relative competence. Roughly, participants who found tasks to be relatively easy erroneously assumed, to some extent, that the tasks must also be easy for others.

Studies on the Dunning–Kruger Effect tend to focus on American test subjects. Similar studies on European subjects show marked muting of the effect; studies on some East Asian subjects suggest that something like the opposite of the Dunning–Kruger effect operates on self-assessment and motivation to improve. As Kruger and Dunning noted, "the miscalibration of the incompetent stems from an error about the self, whereas the miscalibration of the highly competent stems from an error about others."

The Dunning-Kruger Effect refers to a phenomenon in which people who are less adept at a particular skill appear to overestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory superiority), while those who are more highly skilled appear to underestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory inferiority).

biases.name: Zeigarnik Effect in Memory
biases.description: The Zeigarnik Effect refers to a tendency for people to remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks. It is named after Bluma Zeigarnik, who studied this effect in her dissertation.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Soviet psychologist Bluma Zeigarnik first studied the phenomenon after her professor, Gestalt psychologist Kurt Lewin, noticed that a waiter had better recollections of still unpaid orders. In Gestalt psychology, the Zeigarnik effect has been used to demonstrate the general presence of Gestalt phenomena: not just appearing as perceptual effects, but also present in cognition. The Zeigarnik effect suggests that students who "suspend" their study, during which they do unrelated activities (such as studying unrelated subjects or playing games), will remember material better than students who complete study sessions without a break (Zeigarnik, 1927; McKinney 1935).

substeps.title: 8. Has needed resources and permission to perform each action
substeps.description:
We're very unlikely to perform a specific action unless we have the resources we need to perform that action effectively.

There are a number of different things we may fail to have that can prevent us from performing an action:

  • Money - e.g., there may be a cost associated with the action, such as a gym membership fee
  • Supplies - e.g., we may need supplies or equipment to perform the action, such as dumbbells for exercise
  • Technology - e.g., we might not be able to perform the action without sufficiently up-to-date technology, such as a smart phone that's modern enough to run the latest apps
  • Assistance - e.g., if we can't carry an action out alone, we may require assistance; for instance, a person who has severely impaired vision may need assistance in navigating environments that are made for sighted people
  • Transportation - e.g., if we can't get to the right location, we may not be able to perform the required action
  • Permission - e.g., if we can't get the necessary permission to perform an action, such as parental permission for a child or a boss's permission for employees, we may not be able to perform the action
  • Legal Authorization - e.g., if an action goes against rules, laws, or regulations, we are unlikely to be able to carry it out even if it doesn't harm anyone and is beneficial
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't been able to use public transportation that could drop her off near her therapist's office.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't bought vegetarian ingredients to replace the non-vegetarian ones he already had in his home.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't included a line item in her grant budget for doing risk assessments on her projects.

biases.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
biases.description: Fundamental Attribution Error refers to a tendency for people to explain others’ behaviors in a way that overemphasizes their personal characteristics and underemphasizes environmental or situational factors. See also: Actor-Observer Asymmetry
biases.experimentalEvidence:
Jones and Harris hypothesized, based on the correspondent inference theory, that people would attribute apparently freely chosen behaviors to disposition and apparently chance-directed behaviors to situation. The hypothesis was confounded by the Fundamental Attribution Error.

Subjects in an experiment read essays for and against Fidel Castro. Then they were asked to rate the pro-Castro attitudes of the writers. When the subjects believed that the writers freely chose positions for or against Castro, they would normally rate the people who liked Castro as having a more positive attitude towards Castro. However, contradicting Jones and Harris' initial hypothesis, when the subjects were told that the writers' positions were determined by a coin toss, they still rated writers who spoke in favor of Castro as having, on average, a more positive attitude towards Castro than those who spoke against him. In other words, the subjects were unable to properly see the influence of the situational constraints placed upon the writers; they could not refrain from attributing sincere belief to the writers. The experimental group provided more internal attributions towards the writer.

Idea for counteracting this effect: 

- One could point it out and provide suggestions for alternative ways of thinking about the situation in question, with particular attention paid to the environmental factors. Otherwise, the error might lead to unrealistic expectations regarding the relative importance of personal characteristics in achieving the behavior change and its associated outcomes. (This is because, when people observe others experiencing the positive effects of a behavior, they may attribute people's success to personal characteristics rather than to the environmental and social facilitators of the behavior and its outcomes.) Therefore, people may not consider other important barriers and enablers to their behavior change efforts, such as those in their physical and social environment. (The upsides to this might include a greater focus on developing specific personal characteristics and knowledge, which could nevertheless help them in other ways. Thus, the relative (dis)advantages associated with this effect could vary according to which condition for change is most important to meet to facilitate the behavior in question.)

biases.name: No True Scotsman Fallacy
biases.description: The No True Scotsman Fallacy refers to the assumption that one can still defend a universal claim even when faced with a counterexample of it as long as one simply redefines the universal claim as specifically excluding that counterexample.
biases.examples:
For example: "No _true_ American would argue against a private citizen's right to own a gun."

As another example, someone might believe that all people who learn a particular skill must do so through a specific school or training program in order to be considered "truly" skilled at the behavior in question. If they are given counterexamples of people who learned the skill through other mechanisms, they may then claim that the people who learned the skill via those alternative mechanisms are not "truly" skilled.

biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

- Before debating a topic, ask people to outline definitions for crucial terms so that those definitions can be referenced later (and so that debaters can't subtly modify the definitions later).
- Show how one's claim actually does make one a "true Scotsman." For example, "It's _because_ I love America and want it to prosper, and because of how damaging guns are to the fabric of society, that I'm arguing against private gun ownership."
- Over the longer-term, encourage the person to develop probabilistic and nuanced thinking. In this way, they might become less inclined to categorize things as being "always" a certain way.

biases.name: Planning Fallacy
biases.description: The Planning Fallacy is a tendency for people and organizations to underestimate how long they will need to complete a task. This can apply even when they have past experience of similar tasks taking longer than expected. The bias only appears to affect predictions about one’s own tasks; when uninvolved observers predict task completion times, they appear to show a pessimistic bias, overestimating the time taken.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 2003, Lovallo and Kahneman proposed an expanded definition as the tendency to underestimate the time, costs, and risks of future actions and at the same time overestimate the benefits of the same actions. In a 1994 study, 37 psychology students were asked to estimate how long it would take to finish their senior theses. The average estimate was 33.9 days. They also estimated how long it would take "if everything went as well as it possibly could" (averaging 27.4 days) and "if everything went as poorly as it possibly could" (averaging 48.6 days). The average actual completion time was 55.5 days, with only about 30% of the students completing their thesis in the amount of time they predicted.

biases.name: Self-Serving Bias
biases.description: Self-Serving Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby people tend to attribute their successes to internal or personal factors while attributing their failures to situational factors beyond their control.
biases.experimentalEvidence: [taken from description column, these next sentences represent more explanations than descriptions of the bias.] The Self-serving Bias can be seen in the common human tendency to take credit for success but to deny responsibility for failure. There are several possible causes of this bias. People are motivated to protect their self-esteem; they may be attempting to protect their reputation by advertising successes and shifting blame for failures publicly, regardless of their true understanding of the situation. Additionally, success may be more readily available to memory than failure.
