If they fail to do this in a given week, they may attribute their failure to external factors such as work and family commitments, weather conditions, and so on. They may also overlook the contributions of internal factors, such as time management, motivation levels, and procrastination.

biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting or avoiding this bias:

- Point out the other factors that can contribute to specific outcomes (beyond the factors that the person is assuming to be involved). 
- When someone has failed at something, encourage them to acknowledge and learn from the ways in which their personal characteristics could have contributed to that failure. 
- When someone has succeeded at something, encourage them to recognize the situational factors that contributed to their success (e.g., so that they can try to recreate these in the future). 

(There are some similarities between this bias and the Illusion of Control. Self-Serving Bias, however, differs in how people respond to failure, so it presents different obstacles to behavioral change compared to the Illusion of Control.)
biases.content:
Self-Serving Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby people tend to attribute their successes to internal or personal factors while attributing their failures to situational factors beyond their control.

For example, suppose someone aims to engage in five 30-minute sessions of aerobic exercise per week. If they fail to do this in a given week, they may attribute their failure to external factors such as work and family commitments, weather conditions, and so on. They may also overlook the contributions of internal factors, such as time management, motivation levels, and procrastination.

Ideas for counteracting or avoiding this bias:

  • Point out the other factors that can contribute to specific outcomes (beyond the factors that the person is assuming to be involved).
  • When someone has failed at something, encourage them to acknowledge and learn from the ways in which their personal characteristics could have contributed to that failure.
  • When someone has succeeded at something, encourage them to recognize the situational factors that contributed to their success (e.g., so that they can try to recreate these in the future).

(There are some similarities between this bias and the Illusion of Control. Self-Serving Bias, however, differs in how people respond to failure, so it presents different obstacles to behavioral change compared to the Illusion of Control.)
biases.title: Self-Serving Bias

substeps.title: 9. Embodies skills and traits needed to perform each action
substeps.description:
We're very unlikely to perform a specific action unless we have the physical capacities, mental capabilities, and skills needed to perform that action. For instance, even if someone knows how to use a weight machine (as a part of their fitness plan), they may be physically incapable of using the machine if they have a shoulder injury. We may fail to embody all the traits needed to carry out an action for various reasons:
  1. Physical Characteristics—e.g., we may not have sufficient strength or balance to carry out an action
  2. Injuries—e.g., we may have a hand injury that prevents us from carrying out the action safely
  3. Physical Disabilities or Handicaps—e.g., if we are blind, we are not going to be able to carry out actions that require sight
  4. Mental Characteristics—e.g., if we have severe dyslexia, we may find it difficult to carry out actions that involve reading complex material
  5. Skills—e.g., if an action involves a difficult series of steps, we may require training to build the skills necessary to carry out the action
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...her anxiety had been so great that she would have panicked every time she left her home.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't had the skills necessary to cook vegetarian meals.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't had the analytical skills to figure out which potential areas of research posed the most societal danger.
substeps.question: How can you help to ensure that the target person’s or population’s capabilities and skills are sufficiently well-matched to the relevant action?

steps.title: III. CONTINUATION
steps.preface: A person will sustain their new positive behavior and avoid relapse if that person...

substeps.title: 10. Maintains internal attributes and external conditions required to perform future needed actions
substeps.description: We're very unlikely to perform future required actions if, due to the experience of taking earlier actions or due to the passage of time, the conditions mentioned above (Desires, Intends, Remembers, Believes, etc.) fall below adequate levels. For example, after taking the first action in a sequence of actions that compose a new behavior, a person may become discouraged if the action doesn't go well. So, even if the Believes condition was previously met for that action, it may no longer be met after the person has attempted the action once. Or a person may initially meet the Desires condition for a new behavior but might cease to meet that condition as time passes if they forget why they cared about adopting the behavior in the first place.
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have continued visiting her therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't made a firm commitment to the therapist to come to their office every Monday at 6pm.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have continued living a vegetarian lifestyle if...he hadn't pre-planned an exciting trip as a reward for sticking to the diet for 3 months.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have continued reducing the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't made a public commitment during a talk she gave to consider societal risk in all of her future projects.

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY::
Apply the "mental contrasting" technique, which involves focusing on positive aspects of a goal, and the barriers standing in the way of achieving that goal:

1a) Write down or think about several positive aspects associated with completing your goal. For example, if you’re trying to lose weight, those positive aspects could be: looking good, living longer, spending less on healthcare, feeling more lively, being able to stay active, getting your spouse to stop nagging you, etc…
1b) Hone in the most positive aspects. This could be one especially large benefit or a few smaller ones. Then take a few moments to visualize those benefits. The longer and the more detail, the better.
2a) Write down or think about several obstacles in the way of you completing your goal. For example, if you’re trying to lose weight, those obstacles could be: being tempted by snacks, purchasing unhealthy food while shopping, eating too much at dinner, emotional binging, lack of motivation to exercise, etc…
2b) Home in the largest obstacles. This could be one especially large obstacle or a few smaller ones. Then take a few moments to visualize those obstacles. The longer and the more detail, the better.

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY:: How good people feel about a thing doesn't just depend on the outcome; it also depends on their beliefs about what could have happened (e.g., the 2nd place runner might feel bad about it if they expected to get 1st place, but feel great about it if they expected to get 10th place). So if a person is feeling bad about how their new behavior is going, counterfactuals could be presented showing how it could have gone much worse to make them feel better about how it's going, which might prevent giving up.

This strategy combines Mental Contrasting (which involves focusing both on benefits and obstacles standing in the way) and Implementation Intentions (a plan of the form "if situation X happens, I'll take action Y"). The intervention consists of:

- Wish: Clearly identify the desired behavior.
- Outcome: Visualize yourself enjoying a deeply positive experience that you can attain by successfully forming the new habit.
- Obstacles: Following the visualization, identify the most likely obstacle that will cause you to lapse in practicing your habit.
- Plan: Design a strategy to handle the obstacle, in the form "if (obstacle) then (plan)."

biases.name: Choice-Supportive Bias
biases.description: Choice-Supportive Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone who has made a choice between different options later remembers the option that they chose as having more positive attributes than it did at the time (while they remember options they did not choose as having more negative attributes than they’d had at the time).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Research indicates that the process of making and remembering choices yields memories that tend to be distorted in predictable ways. For example, one predictable way that memories of choices are distorted is that positive aspects tend to be remembered as part of the chosen option, regardless of whether they originally part of that option, and negative aspects tend to be remembered as part of rejected options. This may affect a person's regret or approval of past decisions, and may also influence future decision-making.
biases.wasEvidenceCopypastedFromSomewhereIfSoHa: This would need rewording. Depending on the level of depth we want to go into when explaining the evidence supporting the existence of particular biases, I would feel the need to go and find the actual studies before describing and citing them. :S Currently, though, this comes from https://scienceswitch.com/choice-supportive-bias/
biases.examples: For example, someone who chose to undertake an expensive and time-consuming course in order to gain a particular skill may retrospectively remember many positive aspects of the course they chose (even if these did not enter into their decision at the time), and may remember the alternative options as being worse than they were (e.g., they may overestimate how unpleasant or difficult it would have been to learn the skill another way, to gain more work experience while still learning the skill, and so on).

biases.content:
Choice-Supportive Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone who has made a choice between different options later remembers the option that they chose as having more positive attributes than it did at the time (while they remember options they did not choose as having more negative attributes than they’d had at the time).

For example, someone who chose to undertake an expensive and time-consuming course in order to gain a particular skill may retrospectively remember many positive aspects of the course they chose (even if these did not enter into their decision at the time), and may remember the alternative options as being worse than they were (e.g., they may overestimate how unpleasant or difficult it would have been to learn the skill another way, to gain more work experience while still learning the skill, and so on).

Idea for counteracting this fallacy:

  • Help people to notice the ways in which they seek to justify their old behavior. People may often overweight the benefits of the old behavior as a way of justifying that behavior, so helping them to notice that they’re doing this may help them to be more mindful about giving up the old behavior and adopting the new behavior.

biases.name: Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean
biases.description: Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean refers to any case of reasoning that fails to take into account the tendency for random events to exhibit regression toward the mean. “Regression toward the mean” refers to the observation that when sampling a random variable, an extreme (or very unlikely) outcome will, on average, be followed by less extreme outcomes. (Note that the Gambler’s Fallacy does not represent a rational solution to this problem because Gambler’s Fallacy involves the inaccurate belief that a future event “compensates” for a past event, and that is not what is happening in regression toward the mean.)
biases.examples: For example, someone may say, "When his pain got worse, he went to a doctor, after which the pain subsided somewhat. Therefore, he benefited from the doctor's treatment." This person seems to to be assuming that the pain would have continued without the doctor's treatment. In many cases, though, patients tend to visit a doctor at the worst point of their illness, after which time they would get better anyway, even without a doctor's intervention.
biases.automaticKeywords: average, correlation, disregard, percentages, prevalence, probabilities, probability, regression, statistic, statistical, statistics
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this bias:

- It might help to point this out when it occurs and to show it is a fallacy. 
- Provide statistics showing that a person's particular experiences are rare and thus likely to be followed by more common experiences.

John C. Phil D. They are all equally likely E. There is not enough information to make a prediction.
biases.evenMoreNotes: Bob, John, Phil, Tim, and Dave play 40 games of Monopoly against one another. Bob wins 16 of these games, while John wins 9, Phil wins 7, and Tim and Dave each win 4. If they play another 40 games of Monopoly against one another, who is more likely to win fewer games than they won over the course of the previous 40, Bob or Phil?
biases.content:
Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean refers to any case of reasoning that fails to take into account the tendency for random events to exhibit regression toward the mean. “Regression toward the mean” refers to the observation that when sampling a random variable, an extreme (or very unlikely) outcome will, on average, be followed by less extreme outcomes. (Note that the Gambler’s Fallacy does not represent a rational solution to this problem because Gambler’s Fallacy involves the inaccurate belief that a future event “compensates” for a past event, and that is not what is happening in regression toward the mean.)

For example, someone may say, “When his pain got worse, he went to a doctor, after which the pain subsided somewhat. Therefore, he benefited from the doctor’s treatment.” This person seems to to be assuming that the pain would have continued without the doctor’s treatment. In many cases, though, patients tend to visit a doctor at the worst point of their illness, after which time they would get better anyway, even without a doctor’s intervention.

Ideas for counteracting this bias:

  • It might help to point this out when it occurs and to show it is a fallacy.
  • Provide statistics showing that a person’s particular experiences are rare and thus likely to be followed by more common experiences.

biases.name: Endowment Effect (aka Divestiture Aversion)
biases.description: The Endowment Effect refers to a phenomenon in which one places a higher value on objects that they own than on objects they do not.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In one experiment, people demanded a higher price for a coffee mug that had been given to them, but put a lower price on one they did not yet own. The Endowment Effect was described as inconsistent with standard economic theory, which asserts that a person's willingness to pay for a good should be equal to their willingness to accept compensation to be deprived of the good.

biases.content:
Fading Affect Bias in Memory refers to a tendency for the emotions associated with unpleasant memories to fade more quickly than the emotions associated with pleasant memories.

For example, someone who quit binge drinking several months ago may forget their hangovers, vomiting episodes, and the time that they were so drunk that they locked themselves out of their apartment, but they may look back wistfully on the fun they remember having when they used to drink more than they currently do.

Idea for counteracting this bias:

  • Encourage people to keep a diary documenting their affective experiences over time. They can return to previous entries to remind themselves of how emotionally varied (as opposed to uniformly positive) their past experiences actually were. This may be particularly important to ensure the Maintains condition continues to be met (otherwise, the person may be at risk of becoming demotivated if they believe that things were better before they changed their behavior in this way).

biases.name: Fallacy of Gray
biases.description: The Fallacy of Gray is a belief that because nothing is certain, everything is equally uncertain. (That is, this fallacy overlooks the fact that it is possible to quantify and to compare different levels of uncertainty.) Everything may be shades of gray, but there are shades of gray so light as to be very nearly white, and shades of gray so dark as to be very nearly black. Or even if not, we can still compare shades, and say “it is darker” or “it is lighter”. This fallacy is invoked by those who wish to attack a well performing system (e.g., science), by saying that it is still imperfect. This then excuses the imperfections of the invoker’s chosen system.
biases.examples:
For example: "Scientists can't tell us with 100% certainty what happened at the beginning of the universe, so my theory about what happened is just as good as yours."

As another example, someone might be trying to convince their chronically sleep-deprived friend to prioritize getting enough sleep. Upon being presented with a large body of evidence showing the positive health impacts of getting adequate amounts of sleep, the friend may decide not to put any weight on that evidence because "everything in science is uncertain."

biases.benevolentHelper:
Idea for counteracting this fallacy:

- Encourage probabilistic thinking. Say things like: "Just because outcomes aren't certain doesn't mean that we can't know *anything* about how likely they are. You're *much* more likely to make money by working at a steady job than by gambling all day, so you should work on giving up your gambling habit and apply for a job."

biases.name: Historian's Fallacy
biases.description: The Historian’s Fallacy is the assumption that historical decision-makers had the same information available to them and viewed events from the same perspective as the people who later analyze their decisions.
biases.manualKeywords: history, decision, information, perspective, analyze, later, future, past
biases.automaticKeywords: analyze, archived, conclusions, decision, evaluate, extrapolate, future, history, information, insight, insights, later, past, perspective, perspectives, subjective
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

- It might help to notice when it occurs and to plan ways to avoid its recurrence. For example, someone might notice this fallacy (or one very similar to it) coming into play when reviewing their behavior change diary (or a similar method of keeping track of their behavior change goals and their progress towards them). When reviewing their past plans, they might conclude that their past self should have known how the behavioral change plans would work out. As a remedy, the person could notice that they might be falling prey to this fallacy and question their assumptions about the situation. 
- People could also avoid this in the future by additionally recording the _reasons_ that they set specific goals (and made specific plans to meet them). That way, when they later look back on their plans, they might more easily identify the gaps in their knowledge that caused them to form plans in the way that they did. This might lead to less self-criticism as well as to a richer source of information from which they can learn in cases where they have had a behavioral lapse.

biases.name: Hyperbolic Discounting
biases.description: Hyperbolic Discounting refers to the tendency for people to discount the value of rewards that occur later in time, with valuations falling rapidly with earlier delays (e.g., getting a reward now versus in three days) and much less rapidly with later delays (e.g., getting a reward in a year versus a year and three days from now).
biases.experimentalEvidence: The standard experiment used to reveal a test subject's hyperbolic discounting curve is to compare short-term preferences with long-term preferences. For instance: "Would you prefer a dollar today or three dollars tomorrow?" or "Would you prefer a dollar in one year or three dollars in one year and one day?" It has been claimed that a significant fraction of subjects will take the lesser amount today, but will gladly wait one extra day in a year in order to receive the higher amount instead. Individuals with such preferences are described as "present-biased."
biases.examples: For example, someone on a low wage may prefer a $100 gift card given today over a $200 gift card given next month.

biases.name: Moral Luck
biases.description: Moral Luck refers to a situation in which moral value is ascribed to an action or event based on its outcomes rather than on the intentions or actual level of responsibility of the moral agents involved at the time of the action or event.
biases.examples: For example, if two drivers run two different red lights, and (all else being equal) one of them hits a person who was crossing the street while the other gets only a traffic ticket, then people may believe that the person who hit a pedestrian is more morally blameworthy than the other driver, despite the fact that both drivers committed the same original offense (just under different circumstances).

biases.automaticKeywords: destiny, intention, intentions, luck, moral, motive, motives, obligation, outcome, responsibility, responsiblity, value
biases.benevolentHelper:
Ideas for counteracting this phenomenon:

- Point it out when you notice it and encourage the person to reevaluate their beliefs about the relative value (or disvalue) of the behavior in question.
- Point out the factors in a situation that could have turned out differently (particularly with respect to the moral implications of the different possible outcomes). Otherwise, this phenomenon might cause people to think that a given behavior change is morally praiseworthy if it is associated with positive outcomes, even if those outcomes were in part due to chance. The reverse could also occur (moral culpability may be ascribed to the behavior change if it is associated with negative outcomes, even if these were not due to the behavior itself).

biases.name: Outcome Bias
biases.description: Outcome Bias describes a cognitive tendency to judge past decisions in light of their ultimate outcomes, rather than by the quality of a given decision at the time it was made (in light of what was known at that time, which may have been quite different to what is known now).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Baron and Hershey (1988) presented subjects with hypothetical situations in order to test this. One such example involved a surgeon deciding whether or not to do a risky surgery on a patient. The surgery had a known probability of success. Subjects were presented with either a good or bad outcome (in this case living or dying), and asked to rate the quality of the surgeon's pre-operation decision. Those presented with bad outcomes rated the decision worse than those who were presented with good outcomes.

But if we wanted to give more recent evidence, we'd need to look for further info elsewhere. Currently, the cell's content is taken from http://nlpnotes.com/outcome-bias/
biases.examples: For example, someone may plan to progress through a series of steps that should culminate in the establishment of a new, positive habit. If they encounter a setback somewhere along the way, they may decide that their past decisions leading to that point were all poor decisions, even if they were the best decisions that they could have made given what they knew at the time.

- Show people how they made the best decision available to them at the time. This could help to alleviate feelings of guilt or shame about the decision.
- Conversely, show people how they made a poor decision at the time, even if it resulted in (accidental) positive outcomes.
biases.content:

For example, someone may plan to progress through a series of steps that should culminate in the establishment of a new, positive habit. If they encounter a setback somewhere along the way, they may decide that their past decisions leading to that point were all poor decisions, even if they were the best decisions that they could have made given what they knew at the time.

Ideas for counteracting this effect:

  • Show people how they made the best decision available to them at the time. This could help to alleviate feelings of guilt or shame about the decision.
  • Conversely, show people how they made a poor decision at the time, even if it resulted in (accidental) positive outcomes.

biases.name: Prosecutor's Fallacy
biases.description: The Prosecutor’s Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that the accuracy of an accusation against someone has no relationship with the specific context in which the accusation was made. It arose and is usually used in a legal context; it stems from a statistical misunderstanding, and it affects how people weigh evidence against an accused person.
biases.examples: Although this fallacy can refer to a legal phenomenon, the same fallacy could also affect statistical reasoning in other areas. For example, suppose that someone hypothesizes that they will fail at the behavior they are trying to start. If that person then notices some evidence that they are indeed struggling with the behavior, they might conclude that they will be one of the people who permanently fail at this particular goal. In doing so, they might fail to realize that the same evidence would also be present for people who go on to succeed with the behavior change.

Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

- Draw a diagram or sit down and estimate the actual probabilities or odds of the outcomes about which one is trying to think. 
- If you don't already understand Bayes' Theorem, [develop an understanding of it](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZGCoVF3YvM) and [how to use it in everyday reasoning](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lG4VkPoG3ko). 
- If you already know Bayes' Theorem, read about how it can be [useful](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecutor%27s_fallacy#Mathematical_analysis) for trying to avoid the Prosecutor's Fallacy.

It arose and is usually used in a legal context; it stems from a statistical misunderstanding, and it affects how people weigh evidence against an accused person.

Although this fallacy can refer to a legal phenomenon, the same fallacy could also affect statistical reasoning in other areas. For example, suppose that someone hypothesizes that they will fail at the behavior they are trying to start. If that person then notices some evidence that they are indeed struggling with the behavior, they might conclude that they will be one of the people who permanently fail at this particular goal. In doing so, they might fail to realize that the same evidence would also be present for people who go on to succeed with the behavior change.

Ideas for counteracting this fallacy:

  • Draw a diagram or sit down and estimate the actual probabilities or odds of the outcomes about which one is trying to think.
  • If you don’t already understand Bayes’ Theorem, develop an understanding of it and how to use it in everyday reasoning.
  • If you already know Bayes’ Theorem, read about how it can be useful for trying to avoid the Prosecutor’s Fallacy.

biases.name: Rosy Retrospection in Memory
biases.description: Rosy Retrospection refers to a tendency for people to perceive past events more positively than they had perceived them at the time they initially experienced them. Rosy Retrospection appears to be more pronounced with moderately pleasant events (where minor annoyances and downsides seem to fade from memory more dramatically than positive aspects of events).
biases.experimentalEvidence:
[taken from description column, the following sentences are partly just expanding on the description in more detail, and partly addressing a related concept of reference class forecasting] This is reminiscent of the Latin phrase "memoria praeteritorum bonorum" ("the past is always recalled to be good").

The effect appears to be stronger with moderately pleasant events and is usually explained as a result of minor annoyances and dislikes "fading" from memory dramatically faster than positive situations.

Reference class forecasting (the method of predicting the future, through looking at similar past situations and their outcomes) was developed to eliminate or reduce the effect of rosy retrospection in decision-making.
